- Business requirements, which describe the goals and needs of the business
- System requirements, which outline technical and functional specifications
- Functional requirements, which detail specific features and behaviors of the system
- Nonfunctional requirements, which specify performance, security, usability, and other quality attributes

name: Document business processes (OP:457) (SP)
definition:
This involves creating written records of how a business performs its tasks and operations, including details to ensure clear understanding and proper execution.  
- Identifying steps in business processes  
- Clarifying roles and responsibilities  
- Providing instructions for consistent performance

name: Identify the business process problem/issue (OP:458) (SP)
definition: Recognize and define a specific problem or issue within a business process that needs to be addressed.

name: expectations) (OP:459) (SP)
definition:
The expected standards or criteria for performance or behavior that individuals are guided to meet.  
   - Clear goals are set  
   - Performance standards are defined  
   - Behaviors are aligned with objectives

name: Identify data acquisition strategies (OP:460) (SP)
definition:
The process of determining effective methods to gather relevant business data.  
- Surveys  
- Interviews  
- Observation

name: Analyze business processes (e.g., measure efficiency, benchmark metrics) (OP:461) (SP)
definition:
Evaluating business operations to determine their effectiveness and efficiency. This includes:

- Measuring process performance
- Benchmarking against industry standards
- Identifying areas for improvement

name: Recommend improvements to business processes (OP:462) (SP)
definition: Suggest ways to make business processes more efficient and effective by analyzing current procedures and identifying areas for improvement.

name: Identify career opportunities in accounting (PD:337) (SP)
definition:
Recognize various career options in the accounting field, including:
- public accounting
- corporate accounting
- government accounting

name: Explain the roles and responsibilities of accounting professionals (PD:338) (SP)
definition:
Describes the key duties and functions of accounting professionals, including their responsibilities to clients or organizations.  
- Maintaining accurate financial records  
- Preparing financial statements and reports  
- Ensuring compliance with laws and regulations

name: Discuss professional designations for accountants (e.g., CPA, CMA, CIA, CFE, etc.) (PD:168) (SP)
definition:
Professional designations for accountants are certifications that recognize expertise and specialization in various areas of accounting. Examples include:
- CPA (Certified Public Accountant)
- CMA (Certified Management Accountant)
- CIA (Certified Internal Auditor)
- CFE (Certified Fraud Examiner)

name: Describe the services of professional organizations in accounting (PD:339) (SP)
definition:
Professional organizations in accounting offer services that support members' professional development and industry standards. These services include:
- Providing industry resources and information
- Offering networking opportunities
- Delivering certification and training programs

name: Explain the nature of accounting standards (PD:158) (CS)
definition:
Accounting standards are established guidelines that dictate how financial transactions and events should be recorded and reported. They ensure consistency, transparency, and comparability in financial statements. Examples include:
- Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP)
- International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS)
- Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) standards

name: GASB) (PD:295) (SP)
definition:
This indicator refers to understanding the Governmental Accounting Standards Board (GASB) standards that govern financial reporting for government and nonprofit organizations.  
- Comprehend GASB guidelines  
- Recognize the purpose of governmental financial statements  
- Identify key financial statement elements and reporting requirements

name: Reporting Standards (IFRS) (PD:296) (SP)
definition:
A set of accounting rules used internationally to prepare financial statements, ensuring consistency and transparency. It includes standards for:
  - Recognizing revenue
  - Valuing assets and liabilities
  - Disclosing financial information

name: Discuss the levels and types of external financial reporting (PD:340) (SP)
definition:
This performance indicator involves explaining the different types and levels of financial reports prepared by external organizations.  
- Types include: financial statements, annual reports, and SEC filings  
- Levels include: general-purpose, special-purpose, and interim reports

name: Discuss the nature of auditing/attestation standards (PD:341) (SP)
definition:
The standards that guide auditors and attestation services to ensure work quality and consistency.  
- Ethical principles  
- Planning and performing procedures  
- Reporting findings

name: Discuss e-compliance issues in banking services (BL:091) (SP)
definition:
Examining the legal and regulatory requirements that banks must follow when providing online services, including topics such as:

- Data security and privacy
- Customer authentication procedures
- Compliance with financial regulations and laws

name: Discuss federal regulation of lending functions (BL:092) (SP)
definition:
This involves explaining how the government regulates the activities of lenders to protect consumers and ensure fair lending practices.  
   - government agencies involved in regulation  
   - types of regulations concerning lending practices  
   - the purpose of federal regulation in lending

name: Discuss federal regulation of operations functions in banking services (BL:093) (SP)
definition:
Explains how government rules and laws regulate banking operations to ensure safety, fairness, and proper functioning.  
- Includes laws related to banking practices  
- Covers federal agencies overseeing banks  
- Discusses compliance requirements for banking services

name: Discuss the responsibilities of regulatory agencies that oversee the banking industry (BL:094) (SP)
definition: Regulatory agencies that oversee the banking industry are responsible for ensuring financial stability, protecting consumers, enforcing laws, and supervising banks to prevent fraud and maintain trust in the financial system.

name: Comply with banking regulations (BL:146) (SP)
definition: Following legal requirements and rules set by banking authorities to ensure the bank operates legally and ethically.

name: Discuss the importance of meeting and exceeding customer expectations (CR:015) (CS)
definition:
Understanding the importance of meeting and exceeding customer expectations helps build customer loyalty and enhances a business's reputation.  
- Recognizing customer needs and preferences  
- Providing quality products and services  
- Delivering exceptional customer service

name: Recommend bank solutions to meet client needs (CR:031) (CS)
definition: Suggest suitable banking products and services that fulfill a client’s specific financial needs by analyzing their situation and preferences.

name: Assist a customer in the opening of an account (CR:032) (CS)
definition:
Helping a customer open an account involves guiding them through the process and providing necessary information. This includes:
- Explaining account options and features
- Assisting with filling out application forms
- Answering any questions the customer may have about the account

name: (CR:020) (SP)
definition: This indicator involves identifying the characteristics or qualities that demonstrate professionalism and effective performance in a business or leadership role.

name: Interpret loan terms for a client (CR:033) (SP)
definition: Understanding loan terms involves explaining the key details of a loan to a client, including how the loan works and what the client needs to know before borrowing.

name: Explain the purpose of internal accounting controls (FI:343) (SP)
definition: Internal accounting controls are procedures and measures implemented by a business to safeguard assets, ensure accurate financial reporting, and promote operational efficiency. These controls help prevent errors and fraud by directing and monitoring financial activities.

name: Determine the components of internal accounting control procedures for a business (FI:479) (SP)
definition:
Internal accounting control procedures are the methods and processes a business uses to safeguard its assets, ensure accurate financial reporting, and promote operational efficiency. Components include:
- Establishing written policies and procedures
- Segregating duties to prevent errors and fraud
- Monitoring and reviewing financial activities regularly

name: Explain key ratios/terms in banking (FI:543) (SP)
definition:
Understanding key ratios and terms in banking is essential for analyzing a financial institution's performance.  
- Includes important banking ratios such as the loan-to-deposit ratio, net interest margin, and capital adequacy ratio.  
- Defines common banking terms like liquidity, reserves, and interest rates.  
- Explains how these ratios and terms are used to evaluate the financial health of a bank.

name: (FI:544) (SP)
definition:
This performance indicator involves identifying the factors that influence the pricing of products and services.  
- Market conditions  
- Consumer demand  
- Competition levels

name: Describe the nature of bank investment portfolios (FI:608) (SP)
definition:
This indicator explains the basic characteristics of bank investment portfolios, which are collections of financial assets that banks hold to generate income and manage risk.  
   - Types of investments in the portfolio (e.g., bonds, stocks, securities)  
   - The purpose of diversification to reduce risk  
   - The importance of matching investments to the bank’s financial goals

name: Explain economic and marketplace factors impacting bank portfolio quality (FI:609) (SP)
definition:
The factors that influence the quality of a bank's portfolio by affecting the risk and performance of its loans and investments. These include:
- Economic conditions such as inflation, unemployment, and interest rates
- Market trends like changes in real estate or stock markets
- Regulatory policies that impact lending practices and risk management

name: Discuss the impact of technology on the banking industry (NF:117) (CS)
definition:
Explains how technology influences the banking industry by transforming services and operations, including:
- online and mobile banking
- automated teller machines (ATMs)
- digital security measures

name: counterfeit detectors, etc.) (NF:201) (CS)
definition:
Devices used to identify fake products or currency.  
- Counterfeit detectors  
- Currency validation pens  
- authenticity scanners

name: Fill/empty ATMs (Automatic Teller Machines) (NF:116) (CS)
definition: The process of loading or unloading cash and other transactions into or out of Automatic Teller Machines (ATMs). This includes ensuring ATMs are stocked with cash and properly maintained for customer use.

name: (NF:202) (CS)
definition:
Understanding the importance of customer service by demonstrating positive attitudes and behaviors that enhance the customer experience.  
   - Greeting customers politely  
   - Listening actively to customer needs  
   - Responding appropriately to customer inquiries

name: safe deposit boxes, vaults, alarm systems, etc.) (NF:203) (SP)
definition:
Security measures such as safe deposit boxes, vaults, alarm systems, and similar devices are used to protect valuable items and ensure safety.  
   - Safe deposit boxes  
   - Vaults  
   - Alarm systems

name: Discuss procedures for the secure handling of cash (OP:217) (CS)
definition:
Describes the steps and guidelines for securely managing cash to prevent theft or errors.  
- Counting cash accurately  
- Using secure storage methods  
- Following proper transportation procedures

name: Discuss the secure handling of checks (OP:218) (CS)
definition:
Explaining the proper procedures for securely managing checks to prevent fraud or theft.  
- Keeping checks in a safe location  
- Properly documenting check transactions  
- Preventing unauthorized access to checks

name: Explain procedures for detecting and reporting counterfeit currency (OP:219) (CS)
definition:
Describes the steps to identify and report fake money, including key methods and actions to take.  
   - Recognizing signs of counterfeit currency  
   - Using tools or techniques to verify authenticity  
   - Reporting suspicious currency to authorities

name: Describe crimes to which a bank could fall victim (e.g., fraud, robbery, phishing, etc.) (OP:220) (CS)
definition:
A description of various crimes that can target a bank, such as:
- Fraud
- Robbery
- Phishing

name: Discuss the elements and role of a bank security program (OP:221) (SP)
definition:
A bank security program includes the policies and procedures used to protect the bank’s assets, employees, and customers.  
- Elements of a security program include surveillance systems, access controls, and staff training  
- Its role is to prevent theft, fraud, and violence, and ensure safe banking operations

name: Process damaged and/or mutilated currency and coin (OP:271) (CS)
definition: Handling currency that is torn, damaged, or mutilated, ensuring proper procedures are followed for processing or disposal.

name: Order and deposit currency/coin (OP:272) (CS)
definition:
Understanding how to handle and process different types of currency and coins is essential for business transactions.  
- Recognize the correct order and deposit procedures for currency and coins  
- Identify the types of currency (such as bills, coins) used in deposits  
- Ensure proper handling and documentation of deposited currency and coins

name: Deposit checks (OP:273) (CS)
definition:
The process of accepting and recording checks paid by customers into a business account.  
- Endorsing the check  
- Using a deposit slip  
- Depositing at a bank or through an ATM

name: Handle differences in cash received/deposited (OP:274) (SP)
definition:
Ensures that cash received and cash deposited are accurate and match, addressing any discrepancies effectively.  
- Investigate differences in cash amounts  
- Correct recording errors  
- Communicate discrepancies to appropriate personnel

name: Identify requirements for transporting cash (OP:275) (SP)
definition: Understanding the necessary steps and considerations for safely transporting cash, including identifying applicable laws, company policies, and security measures.

name: cashier checks, bearer bonds) (OP:446) (SP)
definition:
A payment instrument that can be used to make transactions, typically issued by a financial institution, and payable to a designated payee or bearer. Examples include:
- cashier's checks
- bearer bonds

name: Discuss the role of the Federal Reserve system in banking operations (OP:276) (SP)
definition: The Federal Reserve system influences banking operations through its roles in managing monetary policy, regulating and supervising banks, providing financial services to banks and the government, and maintaining financial stability.

name: Describe the loan application generating process (OP:277) (SP)
definition: The process of obtaining a loan by completing and submitting a loan application. This includes the steps involved in generating the application and providing necessary information to the lender.

name: Explain the process of credit analysis (OP:278) (SP)
definition: The process of credit analysis involves evaluating a borrower’s financial situation to determine their ability to repay a loan or credit. This includes reviewing financial statements, assessing credit history, and analyzing repayment capacity.

name: Describe factors affecting loan pricing and loan structuring (OP:279) (SP)
definition:
Factors influencing loan pricing and structuring include variables that determine how loans are priced and arranged. These factors encompass:
- Borrower’s creditworthiness
- Interest rates in the market
- Loan amount and term

name: Underwrite a loan application (OP:280) (SP)
definition:
Assessing a loan application involves reviewing and evaluating the borrower's financial information to determine creditworthiness.  
- Analyzing financial statements and credit reports  
- Verifying employment and income details  
- Deciding whether to approve or deny the loan request

name: Discuss the nature of problem loan management (OP:283) (SP)
definition:
The process of managing problem loans involves identifying, monitoring, and resolving loans that are at risk of default or are already delinquent.  
- Recognizes signs of loan trouble  
- Implements strategies to address delinquency  
- Aims to recover funds and minimize losses

name: Discuss the involvement of financial institutions in the real estate industry (OP:186) (SP)
definition:
Explains how financial institutions participate in the real estate industry by providing services such as:
- mortgage loans
- real estate financing
- investment opportunities

name: Explain approaches to real estate lending (OP:281) (SP)
definition:
This performance indicator involves describing different methods used in lending for real estate transactions.  
- Discusses the process of evaluating loan applications and creditworthiness  
- Explains types of real estate loans, such as fixed-rate, adjustable, and interest-only loans  
- Outlines steps in the approval and funding process for real estate loans

name: Discuss the nature of the secondary mortgage market (OP:363) (SP)
definition:
The secondary mortgage market is where existing mortgage loans are bought and sold between lenders and investors.  
- It provides lenders with funds to offer more loans.  
- It helps investors earn returns from mortgage investments.  
- It affects the availability and cost of mortgage financing for borrowers.

name: Describe the functions and responsibilities of the loan servicing department (OP:282) (SP)
definition:
The loan servicing department manages and oversees the ongoing administration of loans after they are issued.  
- Collects payments from borrowers  
- Maintains loan records and accounts  
- Handles customer inquiries and manages loan modifications

name: Describe trust department policies and procedures (OP:364) (SP)
definition:
This performance indicator involves explaining the policies and procedures of a trust department, which are the rules and processes they follow to manage trust accounts responsibly.  
   - Understanding how trust accounts are opened and managed  
   - Knowing guidelines for safeguarding trust assets  
   - Being familiar with how trust transactions are processed and recorded

name: Discuss the administrative duties associated with trusts (OP:365) (SP)
definition:
The administrative duties associated with trusts include managing and overseeing the trust's operations to ensure proper handling of its assets and compliance with legal requirements.   
- Maintaining accurate records of trust assets and transactions  
- Distributing assets according to the trust agreement  
- Ensuring timely filing of legal and financial documents

name: Explain the estate planning process (OP:366) (SP)
definition:
The process of arranging and preparing for the transfer of a person's estate after their death, ensuring their wishes are fulfilled and taxes are minimized. This process includes:
- identifying estate planning goals
- creating legal documents such as wills and trusts
- selecting executors or heirs

name: Manage receipts and payments for a trust (OP:368) (SP)
definition:
This skill involves handling the financial transactions of a trust ethically and accurately. It includes:
- Recording all receipts and payments
- Ensuring proper documentation
- Monitoring account balances to maintain trust integrity

name: inadequate security, poor system design, poor HR policies) (OP:447) (SP)
definition:
This indicator refers to problems that can compromise a business’s information technology system.  
Examples include:
- Inadequate security measures
- Poor system design
- Weak HR policies related to IT security

name: Discuss the nature of operational risk management (OP:448) (SP)
definition: Operational risk management involves identifying, assessing, and controlling risks that can affect a business's daily operations. This includes understanding potential threats and implementing strategies to minimize their impact. Examples include managing financial, legal, safety, and technological risks.

name: Explain career opportunities in banking services (PD:285) (SP)
definition: Understanding career opportunities in banking services involves identifying various roles within the banking industry, such as tellers, loan officers, financial analysts, and branch managers.

name: Discuss professional designations for banking professionals (PD:286) (SP)
definition:
The process of explaining recognized certifications and titles that indicate a banking professional’s expertise and qualifications.  
- Financial certifications (e.g., CFP, CFA)  
- Professional titles (e.g., bank manager, loan officer)  
- Industry designations that demonstrate specialized knowledge and professionalism

name: Describe the services of professional organizations in banking services (PD:287) (SP)
definition:
Professional organizations in banking provide support, resources, and networking opportunities for banking professionals. They often offer:
- Training and certification programs
- Industry updates and research
- Networking events and conferences

name: Describe the nature of retail/business banking processes (PD:204) (CS)
definition:
The process involved in providing banking services to retail or business customers, including conducting transactions, managing accounts, and offering financial products.  
- Processing deposits and withdrawals  
- Managing business accounts and loans  
- Providing financial advice and services

name: Describe types of personal banking products and services (PD:154) (CS)
definition:
A description of various personal banking products and services available to consumers, including:
- Checking accounts
- Savings accounts
- Credit and debit cards

name: Describe types of banking products and services provided exclusively to businesses (PD:423) (CS)
definition:
Includes an explanation of banking products and services specifically offered to businesses, such as:
- Business checking and savings accounts
- Business loans and credit lines
- Merchant services and cash management tools

name: Describe basic teller performance standards (PD:207) (CS)
definition:
The minimum expectations for tellers to perform their duties effectively.  
- Accurate cash handling  
- Providing friendly customer service  
- Following security procedures

name: Describe the importance of selling in the banking industry (PD:298) (CS)
definition:
Selling is important in the banking industry because it helps banks attract and retain customers by promoting products and services that meet their financial needs.  
- Builds customer relationships
- Increases revenue through sales
- Enhances customer satisfaction and loyalty

name: Discuss the nature of loan products (PD:155) (SP)
definition:
Explains the characteristics and features of different types of loan products.  
- Types of loans (e.g., personal, auto, mortgage)  
- Terms and conditions associated with loans  
- How loan products meet various borrower needs

name: Describe trust services available to customers (PD:208) (SP)
definition:
Provides an overview of the services related to building and maintaining customer trust, such as:
- Fraud prevention and fraud protection
- Data security and privacy measures
- Customer authentication and verification processes

name: Describe international services available to customers (PD:299) (SP)
definition:
Provides an overview of the various global or cross-border services offered to customers, including:
- International shipping and delivery options
- Multilingual customer support
- Currency conversion and international payment methods

name: Cross-sell banking products and services (PD:300) (SP)
definition:
The ability to suggest and promote additional banking products or services to existing customers to meet their financial needs and increase sales.  
   - Identify customer needs
   - Recommend suitable products or services
   - Explain benefits to the customer

name: Discuss ethical issues in the banking industry (PD:192) (SP)
definition:
Explaining ethical concerns in the banking industry involves identifying and analyzing moral questions related to banking practices, customer treatment, and financial decision-making.  
  - Fairness and integrity in banking transactions  
  - Confidentiality and privacy of customer information  
  - Responsible lending and avoiding fraud

name: Explain the evolution of commercial banking (PD:191) (SP)
definition:
This involves describing how commercial banking has developed over time, including key changes and advances.  
- the historical development of commercial banking  
- major milestones and innovations  
- trends shaping the industry today

name: (PD:288) (SP)
definition:
This indicator involves understanding and describing various types of promotional strategies used in marketing.  
- Advertising  
- Personal selling  
- Sales promotion

name: Describe the nature of the national banking system (PD:195) (SP)
definition:
The national banking system is a network of financial institutions that provide banking services across a country, supporting the economy by managing money, credit, and payments.  
- Regulates and supervises banks to ensure their safety and soundness  
- Issues currency and manages monetary policy  
- Facilitates financial transactions and supports economic growth

name: Discuss the role of credit unions (PD:200) (SP)
definition:
A financial institution owned and operated by its members that provides banking services.  
- Offers savings and checking accounts  
- Provides loans and credit services  
- Focuses on member benefits and community development

name: Explain the role of savings and loan associations (PD:201) (SP)
definition:
These financial institutions provide savings accounts and loans to members; their role includes:
- accepting deposits from individuals and businesses
- making loans for personal or business needs
- offering financial services to support community development

name: Discuss the nature of global risk (RM:065) (SP)
definition:
The nature of global risk involves understanding the various factors that can threaten the stability and success of international business activities, including potential threats and uncertainties.  
- Economic fluctuations  
- Political instability  
- Natural disasters

name: Monitor third-party relationships for potential risk (RM:066) (SP)
definition: Regularly review and assess relationships with external partners to identify potential risks that could affect the business. This includes monitoring for issues such as compliance problems, financial instability, or reputational concerns.

name: (BL:155) (SP)
definition:
Describe how to identify and assess sales opportunities, including:
- Understanding customer needs
- Recognizing product or service gaps
- Analyzing market trends and data

name: Explain the impact of business customs and practices on global trade (EI:082) (SP)
definition:
Understanding how different business customs and practices influence international trade involves recognizing their effect on trade relationships, negotiations, and transactions.  
   - They can facilitate or hinder the flow of goods and services across borders  
   - They affect communication styles, decision-making, and negotiation processes  
   - They impact legal and ethical standards followed in international markets

name: Describe the nature of business customs and practices in the North American market (EI:083) (SP)
definition:
The understanding of typical business behaviors and traditions in the North American market. This includes:
- Common negotiation styles
- Formalities and etiquette
- Business communication norms

name: Explain the nature of business customs and practices in Western Europe (EI:084) (SP)
definition:
The understanding of typical business behaviors and traditions in Western Europe.  
- Customs related to greetings and etiquette  
- Business communication styles  
- Negotiation practices and decision-making processes

name: Explain the nature of business customs and practices in Eastern Europe (EI:117) (SP)
definition: Understanding the typical business customs and practices in Eastern Europe, including cultural norms, negotiation styles, and communication methods.

name: Explain the nature of business customs and practices in Latin America (EI:085) (SP)
definition:
This involves describing the typical behaviors and traditions used in business settings in Latin America, including:
- Common business etiquette and manners
- Typical communication styles and negotiation tactics
- Cultural customs that influence business interactions

name: Describe the nature of business customs and practices in the Pacific Rim (EI:086) (SP)
definition:
Understanding the typical business customs and practices followed in the Pacific Rim region.  
- Recognizing cultural differences that influence business interactions  
- Identifying common negotiation styles and communication methods  
- Being aware of regional expectations regarding punctuality, formality, and relationship-building

name: Discuss the nature of business customs and practices in the Middle East (EI:087) (SP)
definition: Understanding the traditional and modern ways that business is conducted in the Middle East, including cultural norms and industry practices. This includes recognizing how customs influence negotiations, relationships, and business etiquette in the region.

name: Explain the nature of business customs and practices in South Asia (EI:118) (SP)
definition:
Understanding the general characteristics of business customs and practices in South Asia. This includes how business is conducted based on local traditions, cultural norms, and common practices, such as:
- Building personal relationships before formal transactions
- Emphasizing trust and respect in negotiations
- Following local etiquette and informal communication styles

name: Describe the nature of business customs and practices in Northern Africa (EI:119) (SP)
definition:
The typical business customs and practices in Northern Africa involve understanding cultural norms and behaviors that influence how business is conducted in the region. These include:
- Emphasis on personal relationships and trust-building
- Formal greeting and respectful communication
- Importance of hospitality and social interactions in business settings

name: Discuss the nature of business customs and practices in Sub-Saharan Africa (EI:120) (SP)
definition:
analyzing the typical business customs and practices in Sub-Saharan Africa, including:
- cultural etiquette and communication styles
- negotiation methods and business relationships
- legal and regulatory requirements affecting business operations

name: Discuss the nature of depreciation (FI:345) (SP)
definition: Depreciation is the process of allocating the cost of a long-term asset over its useful life. It explains how the value of assets like equipment or buildings decreases over time due to wear and tear, obsolescence, or age.

name: Describe the nature of cash flows (FI:359) (SP)
definition:
The movement of money into and out of a business over a specific period.  
- Cash inflows from sales, investments, or loans  
- Cash outflows for expenses, purchases, or loan payments  
- The net change in cash during a period

name: Discuss the nature of corporate bonds (FI:523) (SP)
definition:
A detailed explanation of corporate bonds, including their characteristics and how they function as a form of business financing.  
  - Types of corporate bonds (e.g., secured, unsecured)  
  - Sources of bond funding for corporations  
  - How corporate bonds are issued and traded

name: Discuss the cost of corporate bonds (FI:524) (SP)
definition: The discussion of the cost of corporate bonds involves explaining the factors that influence the expense a company incurs when issuing bonds, including interest rates, credit ratings, and market conditions.

name: Discuss the issuance of stock from a corporation (FI:526) (SP)
definition:
Explaining how a corporation issues stock involves describing the process by which a company offers shares to investors to raise capital. This includes understanding the purpose of stock issuance and the basic steps involved.  
   - The company's decision to issue stock  
   - The process of offering shares to the public or private investors  
   - How the stock is sold and the funds are raised

name: Discuss the cost of common stock (FI:528) (SP)
definition: The cost of common stock is the return required by investors to purchase a company's common shares, reflecting the company's risk and expected profitability.

name: Discuss the nature of stock options (FI:729) (SP)
definition:
A discussion about stock options includes explaining their purpose and key features.  
- The right to buy or sell stock at a predetermined price  
- The benefits and risks for investors and companies  
- How stock options are used as compensation or investment tools

name: Discuss the nature of Initial Public Offerings (FI:730) (SP)
definition:
A discussion of Initial Public Offerings (IPOs) involves explaining the process and purpose of companies offering their stock to the public for the first time. Key aspects include:
- The purpose of raising capital for growth or other needs
- The steps involved in the IPO process
- The benefits and risks for the company and investors

name: Describe components of a payment system (FI:733) (SP)
definition:
A payment system includes the methods and processes used to transfer funds between buyers and sellers.  
- Components include:
  - Payment methods (e.g., cash, credit/debit cards, digital wallets)  
  - Financial institutions (e.g., banks, credit unions)  
  - Transaction processing systems (e.g., point-of-sale terminals, electronic transfer networks)

name: Describe components of a collection system (FI:734) (SP)
definition:
The components of a collection system refer to the key parts involved in obtaining and managing customer payments. These include:
- Payment methods (e.g., cash, checks, electronic transfers)
- Accounts receivable records
- Collection policies and procedures

name: Manage bank accounts (e.g., scope of services, fee structures, system integration) (FI:735) (SP)
definition: The process of overseeing and coordinating bank accounts to ensure efficient financial management. This includes understanding the scope of services offered, fee structures, and how systems are integrated with banking operations.

name: Describe the nature of short-term financial management (FI:513) (SP)
definition: The nature of short-term financial management involves planning and controlling a company's financial activities that occur within a year, focusing on maintaining cash flow, managing inventories, and meeting immediate financial obligations.

name: Describe cash management procedures (FI:739) (SP)
definition:
Cash management procedures involve the processes a business uses to handle and control its cash flow. This includes:
- Receiving and recording cash receipts
- Disbursing cash payments
- Reconciling cash balances regularly

name: Explain the use of cash budgets (FI:505) (SP)
definition:
A cash budget is a financial plan that estimates a company's cash inflows and outflows over a specific period. It helps manage cash flow to ensure there is enough cash to meet expenses and avoid shortages.  
 - It forecasts expected cash receipts and payments  
 - It helps plan for periods of surplus or shortage  
 - It assists in making informed financial decisions

name: Analyze the impact of accounts payable schedules on working capital (FI:633) (SP)
definition:
Examining how different accounts payable schedules influence a company's working capital, including:
- The timing of payments to suppliers
- The effect on cash flow
- The overall liquidity position of the business

name: Analyze the impact of accounts receivable collection on working capital cycle (FI:637) (SP)
definition:
Analyzing the impact of accounts receivable collection on the working capital cycle involves evaluating how the speed in collecting payments from customers affects a company's cash flow and overall liquidity.  
- Changes in collection times  
- Effect on cash availability  
- Influence on overall business operations

name: Discuss the impact of employee benefits on business financials (FI:639) (SP)
definition:
The effect that providing employee benefits has on a company's financial health and costs.  
- Types of benefits offered (e.g., health insurance, retirement plans)  
- Impact on company expenses and profits  
- Influence on employee morale and retention

name: Discuss the impact of obsolescence on business expense (FI:641) (SP)
definition:
The effect that outdated or no longer useful equipment, products, or technology has on a business's expenses.  
- Increased costs due to replacing or updating obsolete assets  
- Decreased efficiency affecting profitability  
- Impact on budgeting and financial planning

name: Prepare cash flow budgets/forecasts (FI:507) (SP)
definition:
A financial planning activity that involves predicting future cash inflows and outflows to ensure a business has enough cash to meet its expenses. This includes creating:
- Cash flow budgets
- Cash flow forecasts

name: Analyze cash budget/forecast variances (FI:508) (SP)
definition:
Examining the differences between planned and actual cash receipts and disbursements to identify areas of over- or under-forecasting.  
   - Investigate reasons for variances  
   - Adjust future cash forecasts accordingly  
   - Use variance analysis to improve cash management

name: Evaluate leases (FI:740) (SP)
definition: Analyze and assess the terms, conditions, and financial aspects of lease agreements to determine their benefits and drawbacks.

name: Develop policies to manage trade credit (FI:741) (SP)
definition:
Establishing guidelines to control the extension of credit to customers, ensuring appropriate risk management.  
- credit approval procedures  
- credit limit policies  
- collection strategies

name: Explain the role of capital markets in business finance (FI:360) (SP)
definition:
The role of capital markets in business finance involves providing a platform where businesses can raise funds through the sale of long-term securities.  
- Facilitating the issuance of stocks and bonds  
- Connecting investors with businesses seeking capital  
- Helping businesses manage financial growth and expansion

name: future dividends, the expected rate of return, etc.) (FI:367) (SP)
definition: The expected return on an investment, including future dividends, interest, and capital gains, used to evaluate potential profitability.

name: interest payment for a bond, the effects of interest rates on the price of a bond, etc.) (FI:236) (SP)
definition:
The cost paid by a borrower for using borrowed money, typically expressed as a percentage; it also includes how changes in interest rates can affect the value or price of a bond.  
- Interest payment for a bond  
- Effects of interest rates on bond prices

name: Explain the nature of capital investment (FI:078) (SP)
definition:
The process of understanding why businesses allocate resources to acquire or improve assets to support operations and growth.  
- Includes the purpose of capital investments  
- Covers types of assets involved  
- Explains how investments can affect business success

name: net present value, accounting rate of return, internal rate of return, etc.) (FI:745) (SP)
definition:
A financial analysis method used to evaluate the profitability of investments, including various techniques such as:
- Net Present Value (NPV)
- Accounting Rate of Return (ARR)
- Internal Rate of Return (IRR)

name: Explain the impact of the cost of capital on capital investments (FI:746) (SP)
definition:
The effect that the cost of financing has on decisions to invest in new projects or assets.  
- influences the feasibility of capital investments  
- affects the company's profitability and growth potential  
- determines the attractiveness of investment opportunities

name: Calculate the cost of capital and its components (e.g., debt, equity) (FI:747) (SP)
definition:
This involves determining the overall cost a company pays to finance its operations, including the expense of different funding sources.  
- The cost of debt  
- The cost of equity  
- The overall weighted average cost of capital (WACC)

name: operating cash outflows, terminal flows) (FI:492) (SP)
definition:
Cash payments related to the day-to-day running of a business, including final cash flows at the end of the business’s life. These include:
- Operating cash outflows
- Terminal cash flows

name: Use the time value of money to make business decisions (e.g., projects, investments, etc.) (FI:646)
definition:
The concept of the time value of money involves assessing the worth of money at different points in time to make informed business decisions.  
- Determines the current value of future cash flows  
- Helps evaluate the profitability of projects and investments  
- Considers interest rates and the timing of payments

name: (FI:748) (SP)
definition:
This indicator involves identifying and explaining the financial responsibilities and roles of entrepreneurs.  
- Understanding personal financial management  
- Recognizing business financial obligations  
- Explaining the importance of financial planning in entrepreneurship

name: Identify project benefits and costs (FI:750) (SP)
definition:
Analyzing the positive and negative outcomes of a project to determine its overall value.  
- Benefits, such as increased sales or customer satisfaction  
- Costs, such as expenses or resource use  
- Overall impact on the business or organization

name: Monitor project portfolio (FI:753) (SP)
definition:
The process of regularly reviewing and tracking a collection of projects to ensure they are progressing as planned and meeting organizational goals. This includes:
- Reviewing project status updates
- Assessing project performance against objectives
- Making necessary adjustments to priorities or resources

name: Manage loans (FI:756) (SP)
definition:
The process of overseeing and administering loans to ensure proper handling and repayment.  
- Collecting necessary documentation  
- Distributing funds to borrowers  
- Monitoring loan repayment progress

name: Manage investment portfolio (FI:757) (SP)
definition:
To manage an investment portfolio involves overseeing and making decisions about a collection of financial assets to meet specific investment goals. This includes:
- Monitoring the performance of investments
- Rebalancing the portfolio to maintain desired asset allocation
- Making buy or sell decisions based on market conditions and financial objectives

name: Manage pension investment portfolio (FI:758) (SP)
definition:
The process of overseeing and making decisions about a pension fund’s investment assets to meet long-term retirement obligations. This includes:
- Analyzing investment options
- Monitoring performance
- Rebalancing the portfolio as needed

name: Explain forms of dividends (FI:346) (SP)
definition:
Dividends are payments made by a corporation to its shareholders, representing a portion of the company’s profits.  
- Cash dividends  
- Stock dividends  
- Property dividends

name: Explain the nature of dividend reinvestment plans (DRIPs) (FI:530) (SP)
definition:
A description of how dividend reinvestment plans work, including their purpose and key features:
- Allow shareholders to use dividends to buy more shares of the company
- Often offered at a discounted price or with no commission
- Help investors grow their holdings automatically over time

name: Discuss the financial planning process (FI:502) (SP)
definition:
The financial planning process involves creating a structured approach to managing personal or business finances. It includes:
- Assessing financial situation
- Setting financial goals
- Developing and implementing a plan to achieve those goals

name: Discuss the nature of short-term (operating) financial plans (FI:503) (SP)
definition:
A short-term (operating) financial plan outlines a business’s financial goals and how it will use its resources to achieve them over a brief period, typically one year. It includes:
- Budgeting for daily operations
- Managing cash flow
- Forecasting revenue and expenses

name: revenue) (FI:717) (SP)
definition:
The total amount of money generated from business activities during a specific period.
  - sales of goods and services
  - fees or commissions earned
  - other income sources from operations

name: Discuss the use of cost-volume-profit analysis (FI:718) (SP)
definition:
Analyzing how businesses use cost-volume-profit analysis to understand the relationship between costs, sales volume, and profits.  
  - Identifying fixed and variable costs  
  - Calculating contribution margin  
  - Determining break-even point

name: costing [ABC]) (FI:719) (SP)
definition:
A method of calculating product or service costs by assigning expenses to specific activities or cost centers.  
   - Identifying activities that incur costs  
   - Assigning costs to products based on activities used  
   - Analyzing costs to improve efficiency

name: Distinguish between variable costing and absorption costing (FI:720) (SP)
definition:
A comparison of two methods used for costing products:

- Variable costing: assigns only variable manufacturing costs to products, with fixed costs treated as a period expense.
- Absorption costing: assigns both variable and fixed manufacturing costs to products, including fixed costs in inventory values.

name: return on investment [ROI], customer profitability analysis, etc.) (FI:721) (SP)
definition:
A method used to measure the financial performance of investments or customer relationships.  
- Includes calculations like return on investment (ROI)  
- Analyzes customer profitability to determine the most valuable customers  
- Helps businesses make informed financial and marketing decisions

name: Discuss the role of standard costing in the preparation and analysis of budgets (FI:722) (SP)
definition:
Standard costing helps in preparing and analyzing budgets by comparing expected costs to actual costs.  
- It establishes predetermined costs for products or services  
- It identifies variances between standard and actual costs  
- It aids in controlling expenses and making financial decisions

name: Describe the nature of flexible budgets (FI:723) (SP)
definition:
A flexible budget adjusts the budgeted figures based on actual activity levels, allowing for more accurate financial planning and analysis.  
- It considers changes in sales, production, or activity levels  
- It helps compare actual performance to budgeted expectations  
- It provides a basis for controlling costs and improving financial management

name: Explain the role of transfer pricing in managerial accounting (FI:724) (SP)
definition:
Transfer pricing refers to the methods used to set prices for goods and services traded between divisions within the same company. It plays an important role in managerial accounting by helping managers assess department performance, allocate resources, and make strategic decisions. Factors involved include:
- Determining fair prices forInternal transactions
- Enabling performance measurement of different divisions
- Supporting cost control and profit analysis within the company

name: production, just-in-time [JIT], etc.) on managerial accounting (FI:725) (SP)
definition:
This indicator involves understanding different production systems used in managerial accounting, such as just-in-time (JIT), and how they impact manufacturing processes and cost control.  
Examples include:  
- Production, just-in-time (JIT)  
- Production, batch  
- Production, continuous

name: (FI:768) (SP)
definition: A brief explanation of the specific financial or sales process represented by the indicator, often including key elements or steps involved.

name: Perform responsibility center budgeting (i.e., cost, profit, investment, revenue) (FI:769) (SP)
definition:
The process of preparing and managing budgets for different areas within a business to control financial resources.  
- Cost centers  
- Profit centers  
- Investment centers  
- Revenue centers

name: Discuss the nature of pro forma statements (FI:509) (SP)
definition:
Pro forma statements are projected financial reports that estimate a company’s future financial position. They typically include:
- projected income statement
- projected balance sheet
- projected cash flow statement

name: Discuss the analysis of a company's financial situation using its financial statements (FI:546) (SP)
definition: Analyzing a company's financial situation by reviewing and interpreting its financial statements to assess its financial health and performance. This involves evaluating key financial data and understanding how different statements relate to each other.

name: Discuss external forces affecting a company's value (FI:547) (SP)
definition:
External forces affecting a company's value are factors outside the organization that can influence its performance and worth. These may include:
- Economic conditions
- Competitive environment
- Government laws and regulations

name: Explain how value is created for a company (FI:548) (SP)
definition:
The process of generating benefits or worth that make a company successful. This includes:
- Improving products or services
- Increasing customer satisfaction
- Enhancing operational efficiency

name: accounts, depreciation, debt) (FI:449) (SP)
definition:
The management of financial resources, including the tracking and recording of real and personal property values, expenses, and liabilities.  
- Accounts  
- Depreciation  
- Debt

name: Compare mergers and acquisitions (FI:347) (SP)
definition:
A comparison of mergers and acquisitions involves analyzing the differences and similarities between these two business strategies.  
- Mergers: two companies combine to form a single entity.  
- Acquisitions: one company purchases another.  
- Purpose: to increase market share, expand operations, or gain competitive advantages.

name: Explain the nature of hostile takeovers (FI:536) (SP)
definition:
A hostile takeover is an attempt by a company or individual to acquire control of a company against the wishes of its management and board of directors. This often involves purchasing large amounts of the company's stock to gain influence or control.  
- The target company's resistance or opposition to the takeover  
- Strategies used by the acquiring company  
- The impact on the company's management and shareholders

name: Explain divestiture concepts (e.g., spin-offs, split-ups, etc.) (FI:772) (SP)
definition:
Divestiture concepts involve the process of a company selling or separating parts of its business.  
- Examples include spin-offs, where a company creates a new independent company from a division  
- Split-ups, which involve breaking a company into multiple independent companies  
- Asset sell-offs, where specific assets are sold off to other companies

name: Explain the purpose of internal accounting controls (FI:343) (SP)
definition:
Internal accounting controls are procedures used within a business to ensure the accuracy and reliability of financial information. These controls help prevent fraud, theft, and errors.  
- Safeguard assets  
- Ensure accurate financial reporting  
- Promote operational efficiency

name: Maintain internal accounting controls (FI:480) (SP)
definition:
Establish and follow procedures to ensure the accuracy, security, and integrity of financial records.  
- Documented policies and procedures  
- Regular reviews and audits  
- Segregation of duties

name: Describe manual and computerized treasury systems (NF:240) (CS)
definition:
A description of systems used to manage a company's cash and financial transactions.  
- Manual treasury systems involve paper-based processes.  
- Computerized treasury systems use software to track and manage funds.  
- Both systems help ensure accuracy and efficiency in financial operations.

name: Describe the nature of Extensible Business Reporting Language (XBRL) (NF:241) (SP)
definition: XBRL is a language used to define and exchange financial and business information electronically. It allows data to be shared clearly and consistently across different systems and organizations.

name: Use treasury systems (e.g., cash management, budgeting, forecasting) (NF:242) (SP)
definition:
The process of managing a company's financial resources using computerized systems to handle tasks related to cash, budgets, and financial predictions.  
   - Cash management tools  
   - Budgeting software  
   - Forecasting systems

name: Explain the role and responsibilities of financial management personnel (PD:215) (SP)
definition:
Financial management personnel are responsible for overseeing and controlling the financial activities of a business.  
- Develop financial plans and budgets  
- Analyze financial reports and data  
- Ensure proper financial recordkeeping and compliance

name: Describe the role and responsibilities of risk management personnel (PD:218) (SP)
definition:
The role and responsibilities of risk management personnel involve identifying, analyzing, and addressing potential risks to minimize negative impacts on a business.  
- Develop risk prevention strategies  
- Monitor and assess risk levels regularly  
- Ensure compliance with safety and legal regulations

name: Discuss the role and responsibilities of treasury management personnel (PD:219) (SP)
definition:
It involves explaining the duties related to managing a company's financial resources, including:
- Handling cash flow and banking transactions
- Overseeing investments and debt
- Ensuring compliance with financial regulations

name: etc.) (PD:221) (SP)
definition:
A type of presentation or communication that may include various elements such as:
- PowerPoint slides
- Visual aids
- Verbal explanations

name: GASB) (PD:295) (SP)
definition:
The Governmental Accounting Standards Board (GASB) establishes accounting and financial reporting standards for state and local government entities.  
- Sets guidelines for financial statements  
- Ensures transparency and consistency in government financial reports  
- Helps stakeholders assess fiscal health and efficiency

name: Reporting Standards (IFRS) (PD:296) (SP)
definition:
This performance indicator involves understanding the reporting standards established by the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS).  
It includes recognizing the principles and guidelines used to prepare financial statements according to IFRS.  
- Recognizing the purpose of IFRS standards  
- Understanding how IFRS affects financial reporting  
- Applying IFRS rules to financial statement preparation

name: transactions, financial report filing requirements) (RM:077) (SP)
definition: The process of completing and submitting financial reports and meeting transaction documentation requirements. This includes ensuring proper record-keeping, adhering to filing deadlines, and maintaining accurate financial documentation.

name: Monitor for breach of contract of non-performance related terms and conditions (RM:078) (SP)
definition: Regularly review contracts to identify any violations related to non-performance terms, such as delivery deadlines, quality standards, or payment conditions.

name: Maintain contract compliance documentation (RM:079) (SP)
definition:
This involves keeping records to show that all contractual agreements are followed.  
- Ensuring documentation is complete and up-to-date  
- Tracking compliance with contract terms and conditions  
- Organizing records for easy retrieval and review

name: Evaluate alternative revenue arrangements (e.g., cost-plus pricing, contingent fees) (RM:080) (SP)
definition:
Analyzes different methods of generating revenue to determine the most effective option.  
   - Cost-plus pricing  
   - Contingent fees  
   - Other alternative revenue arrangements

name: Establish monitoring programs for contract-specific revenue arrangements (RM:081) (SP)
definition:
A process to set up systems that regularly review and track revenue from specific contracts.  
- Identifying contract terms and revenue streams  
- Creating procedures to monitor revenue performance  
- Ensuring compliance with contractual and financial standards

name: Develop monitoring programs for restrictive contract requirements (RM:082) (SP)
definition:
Creates systems to regularly check and ensure that restrictive contract requirements are being followed and enforced, including:
- establishing monitoring procedures
- reviewing contract compliance
- addressing any non-compliance issues

name: Establish processes for timely reporting of required information (RM:083) (SP)
definition:
Creates systems to ensure the prompt and accurate reporting of necessary information, including:
- Setting deadlines for reporting
- Collecting and reviewing data regularly
- Communicating reporting procedures to stakeholders

name: Discuss the relationship between risk management and business finance (RM:047) (SP)
definition:
Understanding how risk management relates to business finance involves recognizing how businesses identify, assess, and plan for potential financial risks to protect their assets and ensure stability. This includes:
- Recognizing financial risks such as credit, market, and liquidity risks
- Implementing strategies to minimize or control these risks
- Understanding how effective risk management supports overall financial decision-making and business success

name: Describe types of financial risks (e.g., interest rate risk, equity risk, commodity risk, etc.) (RM:086)
definition:
Different types of financial risks are potential for financial loss resulting from various market factors. Examples include:
- Interest rate risk
- Equity risk
- Commodity risk

name: Discuss the nature of risk measurement (RM:048) (SP)
definition: Risk measurement involves evaluating and quantifying potential uncertainties that could negatively impact business decisions. It includes understanding the types of risks and how they are assessed to help manage or reduce them.

name: Discuss federal and state regulation governing the insurance industry (BL:101) (SP)
definition:
Explains the laws and rules established by federal and state governments that regulate the insurance industry to ensure fair practices and protect consumers.  
   - Federal regulations governing insurance operations   
   - State regulations and licensing requirements  
   - Consumer protection laws within insurance

name: HIPAA, Affordable Care Act) (BL:137) (SP)
definition:
A law or policy related to healthcare privacy and reform that impacts health information management and patient care, including:  
- HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act), which protects patient privacy  
- Affordable Care Act, which aims to expand health insurance coverage and healthcare quality

name: Comply with insurance regulations (BL:152) (SP)
definition: Following laws and rules related to insurance to ensure ethical and legal business practices.

name: Conduct a database search to obtain background information on claimants and witnesses (NF:184)
definition:
This skill involves using a database to gather relevant background information about claimants and witnesses.  

- Search techniques for locating information  
- Identifying credible sources  
- Respecting privacy and confidentiality guidelines

name: Use claims analytics (NF:204) (SP)
definition: Analyzing claims data to identify patterns, trends, and issues that can help improve decision-making and customer service.

name: Use computer smart systems to assist in the underwriting process (NF:134) (SP)
definition: Use computer smart systems to help evaluate and make decisions in the underwriting process by analyzing data and providing recommendations.

name: Use the Internet to determine a potential client's risk (NF:135) (SP)
definition:
Using online resources to assess a potential client's risk involves researching relevant information through the Internet. This process includes:
- Reviewing credit history reports
- Checking for past financial issues or fraud alerts
- Evaluating the client's overall financial stability

name: Notify client in writing when policy is cancelled (OP:287) (SP)
definition: Notify the client in writing when their policy has been canceled to ensure they are informed about the status of their coverage.

name: Explain the elements of an underwriting file (OP:452) (SP)
definition:
An underwriting file includes key information used to evaluate insurance applications.  
- Personal and demographic details  
- Financial history and data  
- Risk assessment and underwriting decisions

name: Interview client (OP:453) (SP)
definition: Conduct an interview with a client to gather relevant information about their needs, preferences, or problems. Examples include asking questions about their goals, budget, and expectations.

name: Determine client's insurance needs (OP:454) (SP)
definition: Assess the amount and type of insurance a client needs by considering factors such as their financial situation, lifestyle, and potential risks.

name: Process insurance documentation (OP:455) (SP)
definition:
The process of handling insurance documentation involves completing, reviewing, and managing the paperwork required for insurance transactions. This includes:
- Filling out insurance forms
- Verifying policy information
- Submitting documents for processing

name: Discuss the nature of insurance claims (OP:188) (CS)
definition: Insurance claims involve the process of requesting compensation from an insurance provider after a loss or incident. This includes understanding the claim process, the types of information required, and the reasons why claims are filed.

name: Process an insurance claim (OP:289) (SP)
definition: Processing an insurance claim involves completing and submitting all necessary forms and documentation to request coverage or benefits from an insurance company.

name: processing the claim (OP:290) (SP)
definition:
The act of completing and submitting a claim for insurance reimbursement or benefits. This includes:
- Gathering necessary information
- Filling out claim forms accurately
- Submitting the claim to the appropriate party

name: Inspect property damage (OP:291) (SP)
definition: Analyze the extent of property damage by examining the damage to structures, equipment, and surrounding areas to determine the severity and potential causes.

name: Evaluate injury claims and needed medical treatment (OP:371) (SP)
definition:
Assess the validity and completeness of injury claims and determine the appropriate medical treatments needed, including:
  - Reviewing injury documentation
  - Verifying claim details
  - Recommending appropriate medical care

name: Assign value to an insurance claim (OP:372) (SP)
definition: Determining the monetary worth of an insurance claim by evaluating relevant information and applying appropriate guidelines to assign a specific dollar amount.

name: Compile claim report (OP:292) (SP)
definition:
A claim report is a detailed document that summarizes and records insurance claims or warranty requests. It typically includes:

- Claim details and information
- Supporting documentation
- The resolution or outcome of the claim

name: Negotiate with claimant (OP:293) (SP)
definition:
Engaging in discussions to reach a mutually acceptable agreement with a claimant, focusing on resolving disputes or claims.  
- Listening actively to the claimant’s concerns  
- Presenting solutions or compromises  
- Reaching an agreeable resolution

name: Discuss the nature of insurance fraud (OP:187) (SP)
definition:
The nature of insurance fraud involves understanding the dishonest act of providing false or misleading information to an insurance company to gain benefits unfairly.  
- Includes intentional misrepresentations or omissions  
- Aims to obtain payments or benefits illegally  
- Can involve individuals or organized schemes

name: Investigate suspected insurance fraud (OP:285) (SP)
definition: Examining situations where insurance claims may be dishonest or fraudulent, including identifying signs of fraud, gathering evidence, and understanding the methods used to detect false claims.

name: Conduct surveillance work (OP:286) (SP)
definition:
Watching and gathering information about competitors, customers, or market conditions to support business decisions.  
   - Observing competitor activities  
   - Monitoring customer behaviors  
   - Collecting market data

name: Explain the nature of pricing and rate-making in insurance (OP:373) (SP)
definition:
This concept describes how insurance companies determine the prices for their policies. It involves the methods used to set appropriate rates that cover costs and generate profit. Elements include:
- Estimating risk and potential loss costs
- Considering expenses and profit margins
- Applying rate-making practices to ensure fair and competitive pricing

name: Describe the nature of the insurance industry (PD:157) (CS)
definition:
The insurance industry involves businesses that provide protection against financial loss.  
- They collect premiums from customers  
- They assess and manage risks  
- They pay out claims to policyholders when losses occur

name: Discuss the role of supervisory/regulatory bodies in the insurance industry (PD:289) (SP)
definition:
Supervisory and regulatory bodies are organizations that oversee and enforce rules within the insurance industry to ensure it operates fairly and ethically.  
- They establish standards and regulations for insurance companies  
- They monitor industry practices and compliance  
- They protect consumers and maintain market stability

name: Explain ethical issues in insurance (PD:290) (SP)
definition:
Understanding ethical issues in insurance involves recognizing situations that raise moral questions and could lead to dishonest or unfair practices.  
- Identifying potential conflicts of interest  
- Recognizing misrepresentation or fraud  
- Considering fairness and honesty in insurance dealings

name: (PD:291) (SP)
definition:
A process that identifies and manages opportunities to improve performance or achieve goals by analyzing data, setting objectives, and implementing action plans.  
- Identifying strengths and areas for improvement  
- Setting measurable goals  
- Developing and executing strategies to reach objectives

name: (PD:224) (SP)
definition:
A measurable skill or knowledge area that students need to demonstrate in a specific marketing or business situation.  
   - It includes understanding concepts and applying skills  
   - It guides the development of competencies needed for success in marketing roles  
   - It is used to assess student performance during competitions or classroom activities

name: Discuss the manner in which insurance companies generate income (PD:222) (SP)
definition: Insurance companies generate income primarily through premiums paid by policyholders, investment earnings on their reserves, and fees for additional services.

name: Explain the use of state risk pool programs (PD:223) (SP)
definition:
A explanation of how state risk pool programs function to provide health insurance coverage for individuals who might not qualify elsewhere.  
- They pool resources to cover high-risk or uninsured individuals  
- They help stabilize insurance markets  
- They support access to affordable health coverage for vulnerable populations

name: (PD:292) (SP)
definition: This performance indicator involves understanding and applying ethical decision-making principles in business situations.

name: Explain career opportunities in insurance (PD:293) (SP)
definition: Describes various career options available within the insurance industry, including roles such as agents, underwriters, and claims adjusters.

name: Discuss licensing and certification in the insurance industry (PD:225) (SP)
definition:
Licensing and certification are processes that validate a person's qualifications and authorize them to sell insurance products. 
- Licensing involves obtaining a state-issued credential to sell insurance.
- Certification is a recognition of specialized knowledge or skills within the industry.
- Both are important for legal and professional standards in insurance sales.

name: Describe the services of professional organizations in insurance (PD:294) (SP)
definition:
Professional organizations in insurance provide support, resources, and networking opportunities for industry professionals. They offer:
- Industry standards and best practices
- Certification and training programs
- Networking events and conferences

name: Describe components of automobile insurance coverage (PD:319) (SP)
definition:
This performance indicator involves explaining the key parts of automobile insurance coverage, including:
- Liability coverage (for damages to others)
- Collision coverage (for damage to your own vehicle)
- Comprehensive coverage (for non-collision damages like theft or weather)

name: Discuss the nature of health insurance coverage (PD:320) (SP)
definition:
An explanation of how health insurance coverage works and its importance.  
- Types of health insurance plans  
- Benefits of having health insurance  
- How health insurance helps manage medical costs

name: Discuss components of homeowners/renters insurance (PD:321) (SP)
definition:
This indicator involves explaining the key parts of homeowners and renters insurance policies.  
- Property coverage for personal belongings and the dwelling  
- Liability protection against accidents or injuries on the property  
- Additional living expenses coverage if displaced from the home

name: Explain the nature of liability insurance (PD:322) (SP)
definition:
Liability insurance is a type of coverage that protects individuals or businesses from financial loss if they are held responsible for causing damage or injury to others. It generally includes:
- Covering legal costs
- Paying for damages awarded in a lawsuit
- Protecting against claims for personal or property harm

name: Discuss the nature of life insurance (PD:323) (SP)
definition:
Explains the basic concept and purpose of life insurance.  
- Provides financial protection for beneficiaries  
- Involves paying premiums in exchange for a death benefit  
- Helps manage risk and provide peace of mind

name: Describe the nature of disability insurance (PD:324) (SP)
definition:
Disability insurance provides financial protection by replacing a portion of income if an individual becomes unable to work due to illness or injury.  
- Offers income replacement during disability  
- Typically includes short-term and long-term coverage  
- Helps cover medical and living expenses while disabled

name: Discuss components of flood and earthquake insurance (PD:325) (SP)
definition:
An explanation of the key elements included in flood and earthquake insurance policies, such as:
- Coverage limits
- Exclusions and limitations
- Claim process and required documentation

name: Discuss the nature of title insurance (PD:326) (SP)
definition:
Title insurance is a type of insurance that protects buyers and lenders from financial loss due to defects or issues with the property's title.  
- It ensures clear ownership of the property.  
- It covers problems that were unknown during the title search.  
- It provides peace of mind to the property owner and lender.

name: Describe components of commercial property insurance (PD:327) (SP)
definition:
Components of commercial property insurance include coverage that protects against damage or loss to business buildings and contents, such as:
- Building structure coverage
- Business personal property coverage
- Additional coverages like loss of income or debris removal

name: Explain the nature of commercial liability insurance (PD:328) (SP)
definition:
A type of insurance that provides coverage for damages or injuries caused by a business to other people or their property.  
- Protects the business financially from lawsuits and claims  
- Generally covers legal costs and settlement or repair costs  
- Helps businesses manage risks associated with their operations

name: Discuss the nature of unemployment insurance (PD:329) (SP)
definition:
Unemployment insurance is a government program that provides temporary financial assistance to workers who have lost their jobs through no fault of their own. It helps support individuals while they search for new employment, and its key features include:
- eligibility requirements
- funding sources
- duration of benefits

name: Explain the nature of workers compensation insurance (PD:330) (SP)
definition: A description of workers compensation insurance, including its purpose and how it provides benefits for employees who are injured or become ill due to work-related activities.

name: Discuss the nature of Medicaid (PD:331) (SP)
definition:
Explains the basic purpose and key features of Medicaid, a government program that provides healthcare coverage for eligible individuals and families.  
- Federal and state partnership  
- Covers low-income and vulnerable populations  
- Includes services like hospital care, doctor visits, and prescriptions

name: Explain the nature of Medicare (PD:332) (SP)
definition:
A description of the basic purpose and function of Medicare, including its role as a government health insurance program for certain populations.
- Provides health coverage for seniors aged 65 and older
- Covers some younger individuals with disabilities
- Offers specific hospital and medical services

name: Discuss the nature of long-term care insurance (PD:333) (SP)
definition:
Explains the purpose and characteristics of long-term care insurance, including:
- coverage for extended medical and personal care services
- options for policyholders to select specific benefits
- differences between long-term care insurance and health insurance

name: Discuss the role of life insurance in investment, retirement, and estate planning (PD:334) (SP)
definition:
This involves explaining how life insurance can be used as a financial tool in planning for investment, retirement, and estate transfer.  
   - It provides a source of savings or investment growth  
   - It offers financial security and income replacement during retirement  
   - It helps transfer wealth efficiently to heirs and beneficiaries

name: Explain the nature of annuities (PD:308) (SP)
definition:
A financial product that provides a series of payments at regular intervals in exchange for an initial lump sum.  
- Fixed payments  
- Variable payments (depending on investment performance)  
- Payments made for a specific period or for life

name: Discuss the nature of domestic and international business insurance (PD:335) (SP)
definition:
The nature of domestic and international business insurance involves understanding how insurance protects businesses from risks related to their operations within a country or across borders. This includes:
- The purpose and types of insurance coverage for businesses
- Differences between domestic and international insurance policies
- How insurance helps manage risks related to exports, imports, and global operations

name: Evaluate an existing client's insurance needs (PD:336) (SP)
definition:
Assess an existing client's insurance requirements by analyzing their personal or business circumstances to determine appropriate coverage needs. This includes considering:
- Types of insurance policies needed
- Coverage amounts
- Any gaps or excess coverage

name: Explain insurance underwriting techniques and processes (RA:004) (SP)
definition:
The process of evaluating and assessing insurance applications to determine coverage eligibility and premium rates. This includes:
- Reviewing applicant information and risk factors
- Analyzing potential risks
- Making decisions on policy issuance and terms

name: Discuss the nature of credit-based insurance scores (RA:002) (SP)
definition:
An explanation of how credit-based insurance scores work and their role in determining insurance eligibility and rates.  
- How credit scores are used to predict insurance risk  
- Factors that influence insurance scores  
- The impact of credit scores on insurance premiums

name: Explain the importance of actuarial science in the insurance industry (RA:001) (SP)
definition: Actuarial science is important in the insurance industry because it helps assess risk and determine appropriate policy rates. It involves analyzing data and using mathematical models to predict future events, such as accidents or illnesses, to ensure the financial stability of insurance companies.

name: Underwrite an insurance policy (RA:003) (SP)
definition:
The process of evaluating and determining the appropriate coverage, premiums, and terms for an insurance policy.

- Reviewing the applicant’s information
- Assessing risks associated with the policy
- Setting coverage details and premium costs

name: Discuss ethical considerations in the securities and investments industry (BL:104) (SP)
definition:
Understanding ethical considerations involves evaluating the standards and moral principles that guide behavior in the securities and investments industry. This includes:
- maintaining honesty and integrity in transactions
- avoiding conflicts of interest
- complying with laws and regulations

name: Discuss laws and regulations governing the securities and investments industry (BL:105) (SP)
definition:
An explanation of the legal rules and regulations that oversee the securities and investments industry, including:
- the purpose of these laws
- key regulatory agencies
- main compliance requirements

name: Comply with securities and investments regulations (BL:151) (SP)
definition:
Understand and follow the laws and rules that govern securities and investments to ensure ethical and legal business practices. This includes:
- Adhering to federal and state securities laws
- Following regulations set by financial authorities
- Ensuring accurate and honest communication about investments

name: Initiate correspondence with customers regarding market activity (CO:207) (SP)
definition:
The action of starting communication with customers to discuss or inform them about market activity.  
- Sending emails or letters about sales or promotions  
- Making phone calls to update customers on product availability  
- Responding to customer inquiries regarding market changes

name: Develop communication plans based on customer preferences (CO:208) (SP)
definition:
Creates communication plans tailored to customer preferences, considering how and when customers want to receive information.  
- Identifies customer communication preferences  
- Selects appropriate communication channels  
- Outlines methods and timing for message delivery
